A 'desert' is a landscape or region of land that is very dry because of low
rainfall amounts (precipitation), often has little coverage by plants, and in
which streams dry up unless they are supplied by water from outside areas. Marshak, Stephen (2009) Essentials of Geology, 3rd ed., W. W. Norton &
Company, p. 452, ISBN 0393196569. Deserts can also be described as areas
where more water is lost by evapotranspiration than falls as precipitation. Desert plants must have special adaptations to survive with
this little water. Deserts generally receive less than of rain (precipitation)
each year. Semideserts or steppes are regions which receive
between and .
